div.head:
402. Robert Southey to Grosvenor Charles Bedford, 27 April 1799 Address: To/ Grosvenor Charles Bedford Esqr/ Exchequer/ London/ Single
Postmarks: [partial] BR/ AP; B/AP/ 29/ 99
Endorsement: 27 April. 1799
MS: Bodleian Library, MS Eng. Lett. c. 23
Unpublished.
div.p: Tom & I expect to be in town together to breakfast on Tuesday morning, at the Saracens head, Friday Street, CheapsideAn inn in London. Side. I will call at the ExchequerBedford’s place of work. as near one as I can. before that time we shall have made our arrangements. Tom expects to stay in London but a few days. if Burnett will walk with me I shall eat my dinnersSouthey was still – nominally – studying law. He needed to dine at Gray’s Inn in order to fulfil the terms of his legal studies. & walk off. Burnett arrives in town from Yarmouth at the same time with us. if he will not ramble & you have a bed at Brixton I will buy a Dutch Grammar & study Jacob Cats.The Dutch statesman and poet, Jacob Cats (1577–1660). with my present feelings – it is almost ten o clock & I am tired hand & foot with walking & reviewing – I should look on with more satisfaction to reading & translating Dutch poetry than to wandering over the mountain sublimity of Switzerland. I want books & quietness – the less fatigue the better, & the less mental emotion. agitation is become painful.

I shall bring Madoc with me. 12 books are written out of 15.Southey completed a fifteen-book version of Madoc in 1797-1799; the poem was heavily revised before its publication in 1805. should I be your guest at Brixton it will be the second epic poem that I shall finish there.The first was Joan of Arc, the original draft of which was completed at the Bedfords’ home in Brixton in 1793. I wish to read it to you, if you can bear the almost improvisatore tone of one to whose manner of reading you are not accustomed.
Tom is recovered. I am not – & this is my ill time. however I begin to sleep well without opiates, & hope to be soon as drowsy ever as ever at the hour of owl-rising.

I want to be introduced to Pye – & for the same reason fancy he would like to be introduced to me, that we <may> talk about Alfred.The Poet Laureate Henry James Pye (1745–1813; DNB), whose Alfred, An Epic Poem in Six Books was published in 1801. never did I go to London with the prospect of seeing so many friends – yet never did I leave home with more reluctance. exertion, fatigue, alteration are hateful to me. my sensations are such that like certain politicians I think all changes must be needs for the worse.
Now I have no wish for the fortnights vacancy but your library every morning & you every evening. tomorrow I shall think again of my knapsack & a ramble.

closer.salute: yrs – huzza! as sleepily as ever
